article.title: Timeline_of_chemical_element_discoveries
article.paragraph: The discovery of theChemical elementelementsknown to exist today is presented here in chronological order. The elements are listed generally in the order in which each was first defined as the pure element, as the exact date of discovery of most elements cannot be accurately defined.
Given is each element'slist of elements by namename,atomic number, year of first report, name of the discoverer, and some notes related to the discovery.
article.heading: Table
Unrecorded discoveries

tablerow.tablecell: 9000 BCE
6000 BCE

Copper was probably the first metal mined and crafted by humans.cite webhttp://www.rameria.com/inglese/history.htmlCopper HistoryRameria.com2008-09-12It was originally obtained as a native metal and later from the smelting of ores. Earliest estimates of the discovery of copper suggest around 9000 BCE in the Middle East. It was one of the most important materials to humans throughout thecopper agecopperandbronze ages. Copper beads dating from 6000 BCE have been found inatal Hyk, Anatolia.CSA Discovery Guides, A Brief History of Copper
7000 BCE
3800 BCE

It is believed that lead smelting began at least 9,000 years ago, and the oldest known artifact of lead is a statuette found at the temple ofOsirison the site of Abydos dated circa 3800 BCE.cite webhttp://www.lead.org.au/lanv2n3/lanv2n3-22.htmlThe History of Lead – Part 3Lead.org.au2008-09-12
Before 6000 BCE
ca. 4400 BCE
The oldest golden treasure in the world, dating from 4,600 BC to 4,200 BC, was discovered at the burial siteVarna Necropolis.
Before 5000 BCE
ca. 4000 BCE

Estimated to have been discovered shortly after copper and gold.47 Silvercite webhttp://chemistry.about.com/od/elementfacts/a/silver.htmSilver Facts – Periodic Table of the ElementsChemistry.about.com2008-09-12
Before 5000 BCE
4000 BCE
Unknown;seeHistory of ferrous metallurgy
Egypt

There is evidence that iron was known from before 5000 BCE.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym26 IronElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12The oldest known iron objects used by humans are some beads ofmeteoric iron, made in Egypt in about 4000 BCE. The discovery of smelting around 3000 BCE led to the start of theiron agearound 1200 BCECite bookWeeksMary ElviraMary Elvira WeeksLeichester, Henry M.1968Discovery of the ElementsJournal of Chemical EducationEaston, PAElements Known to the Ancients29–40LCCCN 68-152170-7661-3872-0and the prominent use of iron for tools and weapons.cite webhttp://courses.wcupa.edu/jones/his101%5Cmisc%5Cpersia.htmNotes on the Significance of the First Persian Empire in World HistoryCourses.wcupa.edu2008-09-12
3750 BCE

The earliest known use of charcoal was for the reduction of copper, zinc, and tin ores in the manufacture of bronze, by the Egyptians and Sumerians.cite webhttp://www.caer.uky.edu/carbon/history/carbonhistory.shtmlHistory of Carbon and Carbon Materials – Center for Applied Energy Research – University of KentuckyCaer.uky.edu2008-09-12Diamondswere probably known as early as 2500 BCE.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/4555235.stmChinese made first use of diamondBBC News17 May 20052007-03-21The first true chemical analyses were made in the 18th century,cite bookFerchault de RéaumurR-A1722L'art de convertir le fer forgé en acier, et l'art d'adoucir le fer fondu, ou de faire des ouvrages de fer fondu aussi finis que le fer forgé (English translation from 1956)Paris, Chicagoand in 1789 carbon was listed byAntoine Lavoisieras an element.cite webSenese, FredSeptember 9, 2009http://antoine.frostburg.edu/chem/senese/101/inorganic/faq/discovery-of-carbon.shtmWho discovered carbon?[[Frostburg State University]]2007-11-24Dead linkSeptember 2010H3llBot
3500 BCE
2000 BCE
Unknown;seeTin#History

First smelted in combination with copper around 3500 BCE to producebronze.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym50 TinElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12The oldest artifacts date from around 2000 BCE.cite webhttp://neon.mems.cmu.edu/cramb/Processing/history.htmlHistory of MetalsNeon.mems.cmu.edu2008-09-12
Before 2000 BCE
First used at least 4,000 years ago.cite webhttp://www.georgiagulfsulfur.com/history.htmSulfur HistoryGeorgiagulfsulfur.com2008-09-12Recognized as an element byAntoine Lavoisierin 1777.
Before 2000 BCE
1500 BCE
Egypt

Known to ancient Chinese and Indians before 2000 BCE, and found in Egyptian tombs dating from 1500 BCE.cite webMercury and the environment — Basic facts''[[Environment Canada]], Federal Government of Canada''2004http://www.ec.gc.ca/MERCURY/EN/bf.cfm2008-03-27
Before 1000 BCE
1000 BCE

link.target: History of metallurgy in the Indian subcontinent

tablerow.tablecell: Extracted as a metal since antiquity (before 1000 BCE) by Indian metallurgists, but the true nature of this metal was not understood in ancient times. Identified as a unique metal by the metallurgistRasaratna Samuccayain 800Craddock, P. T. et al. (1983), "Zinc production in medieval India",World Archaeology15(2), Industrial Archaeology, p. 13and by the alchemistParacelsusin 1526.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym30 ZincElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12Isolated byAndreas Sigismund Marggrafin 1746.cite bookWeeksMary ElviraMary Elvira Weeks1933The Discovery of the ElementsJournal of Chemical EducationEaston, PAIII. Some Eighteenth-Century Metals0-7661-3872-021
2500 BCE/1250 CE
Bronze age

In use in the early bronze age; Albertus Magnus was the first European to isolate the element in 1250.cite webhttp://periodic.lanl.gov/33.shtmlArsenic[[Los Alamos National Laboratory]]3 March 2013In 1649,Johann Schrderpublished two ways of preparing elemental arsenic.
3000 BCE

In widespread use in Egypt and the Middle East.cite journalAPPLICATION OF LEAD ISOTOPE ANALYSIS TO A WIDE RANGE OF LATE BRONZE AGE EGYPTIAN MATERIALSArchaeometry2006-11-01484657–66910.1111/j.1475-4754.2006.00279.xSHORTLANDA. J.

article.heading: Recorded discoveries

tablerow.tablecell: Prepared from urine, it was the first element to be chemically discovered.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym15 PhosphorusElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Proved that the blue color of glass is due to a new kind of metal and not bismuth as thought previously.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym27 CobaltElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

First description of a metal found inSouth Americangold was in 1557 byJulius Caesar Scaliger. Ulloa published his findings in 1748, butCharles Wood (scientist)Sir Charles Woodalso investigated the metal in 1741. First reference to it as a new metal was made byWilliam Brownriggin 1750.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym78 PlatinumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Found by attempting to extract copper from the mineral known asfake copper(now known asniccolite).cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym28 NickelElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Definitively identified by Claude Franois Geoffroy in 1753.cite webhttp://periodic.lanl.gov/83.shtmlBismuth[[Los Alamos National Laboratory]]3 March 2013

Black observed thatmagnesia alba(MgO) was notquicklime(CaO). Davy isolated the metal electrochemically fromMagnesia (mineral)magnesia.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym12 MagnesiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Cavendish was the first to distinguishchemH2from other gases, although Paracelsus around 1500, Robert Boyle, and Joseph Priestley had observed its production by reacting strong acids with metals. Lavoisier named it in 1793.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym01 HydrogenElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12cite bookThe Encyclopedia of the Chemical ElementsAndrewsA. C.Reinhold Book CorporationNew York1968272Clifford A. HampelOxygen68-29938

Obtained it by heatingmercuric oxideandnitratesin 1771, but did not publish his findings until 1777.Joseph Priestleyalso prepared this newairby 1774, but only Lavoisier recognized it as a true element; he named it in 1777.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym08 OxygenElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12cite bookThe Encyclopedia of the Chemical ElementsCookGerhard A.Lauer, Carol M.Reinhold Book CorporationNew York1968499–500Clifford A. HampelOxygen68-29938

He discovered Nitrogen while he was studying at theUniversity of Edinburgh.cite bookRozaGregThe Nitrogen Elements: Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Arsenic, Antimony, Bismuth201097814358533557He showed that the air in which animals had breathed, even after removal of the exhaled carbon dioxide, was no longer able to burn a candle. Carl Wilhelm Scheele, Henry Cavendish, and Joseph Priestley also studied the element at about the same time, and Lavoisier named it in 1775-6.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym07 NitrogenElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Obtained it fromhydrochloric acid, but thought it was an oxide. Only in 1808 did Humphry Davy recognize it as an element.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym17 ChlorineElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Distinguishedpyrolusiteas the calx of a new metal.Ignatius Gottfred Kaimalso discovered the new metal in 1770, as did Scheele in 1774. It was isolated by reduction ofmanganese dioxidewith carbon.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym25 ManganeseElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Scheele distinguished a new earth (BaO) in pyrolusite and Davy isolated the metal byelectrolysis.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym56 BariumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Scheele recognised the metal as a constituent ofMolybdenitemolybdena.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym42 MolybdenumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Muller observed it as an impurity in gold ores from Transylvania.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym52 TelluriumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Juan Jos ElhuyarJ.andFausto ElhuyarF. Elhuyar

Bergman obtained fromscheelitean oxide of a new element. The Elhuyars obtainedtungstic acidfromwolframiteand reduced it with charcoal.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym74 TungstenElements.vanderkrogt.netIUPAC2008-09-12

Cruikshank andAdair Crawfordin 1790 concluded thatstrontianitecontained a new earth. It was eventually isolated electrochemically in 1808 by Humphry Davy.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym38 StrontiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

tablerow.tablehead: The first modern list of chemical elements containing, among others, 29 elements of those known then.cite webhttp://homepage.mac.com/dtrapp/periodic.f/lavoisier.htmlLavoisierHomepage.mac.com2008-09-12Dead linkSeptember 2010H3llBotHe also redefined the term "element". Until then, no metals except mercury were considered elements.

tablerow.tablecell: Klaproth identified a new element inzirconia.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/chronology_list.phpChronology – ElementymologyElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12Cite journalZirconium2007–2008CRC Handbook of Chemistry and PhysicsLideDavid R.442New YorkCRC Press978-0-8493-0488-0

Mistakenly identified auranium oxideobtained frompitchblendeas the element itself and named it after the recently discovered planetUranus.cite journalChemische Untersuchung des Uranits, einer neuentdeckten metallischen SubstanzM. H. KlaprothChemische Annalen21789387–403cite journalRecherches Sur L'UraniumE.-M. Péligot[[Annales de chimie et de physique]]5518425–47http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k34746s/f4.table

Gregor found an oxide of a new metal inilmenite; Martin Heinrich Klaproth independently discovered the element inrutilein 1795 and named it. The pure metallic form was only obtained in 1910 byMatthew A. Hunter.cite webTitaniumhttp://periodic.lanl.gov/elements/22.html20042006-12-29[[Los Alamos National Laboratory]]cite book''The Encyclopedia of the Chemical Elements''1968Barksdale, Jelks[[Reinhold Book Corporation]][[Skokie, Illinois]]732–38 "Titanium"LCCCN 68-29938

Discovered ingadolinite, but Mosander showed later that its ore,yttria, contained more elements.cite journalhttp://books.google.com/?idKongl. Vet. Acad. Handl.XV137Introduction to the Rarer ElementsBrowning, Philip Embury1917cite journal1796Crell Anal.I313

Vauquelin discovered the trioxide incrocoiteore, and later isolated the metal by heating the oxide in a charcoal oven.Cite journalhttp://books.google.com/?idJournal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry, and the Art17981463Memoir on a New Metallic Acid which exists in the Red Lead of SibiriaLouis NicolasVauquelin
Friedrich WhlerF. WhlerandAntoine BussyA. Bussy

Vauquelin discovered the oxide inberyland emerald, and Klaproth suggested the present name around 1808.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym04 BerylliumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Ro found the metal invanadinitebut retracted the claim afterHippolyte Victor Collet-Descotilsdisputed it. Sefstrm isolated and named it, and later it was shown that Ro had been right in the first place.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym23 VanadiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Hatchett found the element incolumbiteore and named itcolumbium.Heinrich Roseproved in 1844 that the element is distinct from tantalum, and renamed itniobiumwhich was officially accepted in 1949.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym41 NiobiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Ekeberg found another element in minerals similar to columbite and in 1844, Heinrich Rose proved that it was distinct from niobium.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym73 TantalumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Wollaston discovered it in samples of platinum from South America, but did not publish his results immediately. He had intended to name it after the newly discoveredasteroid,Ceres (dwarf planet)Ceres, but by the time he published his results in 1804, cerium had taken that name. Wollaston named it after the more recently discovered asteroid2 PallasPallas.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym46 PalladiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Martin Heinrich KlaprothH. Klaproth, J. Berzelius, andWilhelm HisingerW. Hisinger

Berzelius and Hisinger discovered the element inceriaand named it after the newly discovered asteroid (then considered a planet), Ceres. Klaproth discovered it simultaneously and independently in some tantalum samples. Mosander proved later that the samples of all three researchers had at least another element in them,lanthanum.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym58 CeriumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Tennant had been working on samples of South American platinum in parallel with Wollaston and discovered two new elements, which he named osmium and iridium.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym76 OsmiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Tennant had been working on samples of South American platinum in parallel with Wollaston and discovered two new elements, which he named osmium and iridium, and published the iridium results in 1804.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym77 IridiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Wollaston discovered and isolated it from crude platinum samples from South America.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym45 RhodiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Davy discovered it by using electrolysis onpotash.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym19 PotassiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Davy discovered it a few days after potassium, by using electrolysis onsodium hydroxide.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym11 SodiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Davy discovered the metal by electrolysis ofquicklime.
Joseph Louis Gay-LussacL. Gay-LussacandLouis Jacques ThnardL.J. Thnard

On June 21, 1808, Lussac and Thnard announced a new element inboric acidsedative salt, Davy announced the isolation of a new substance from boracic acid soon afterwards.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym05 BoronElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Andr-Marie Ampre predicted an element analogous to chlorine obtainable fromhydrofluoric acid, and between 1812 and 1886 many researchers tried to obtain this element. It was eventually isolated by Moissan.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym09 FluorineElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Courtois discovered it in the ashes ofseaweed.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym53 IodineElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Arfwedson discovered the alkali inpetalite.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym03 LithiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Karl Samuel Leberecht HermannS. L Hermann,Friedrich StromeyerF. Stromeyer, and J.C.H. Roloff

tablecell.italics: S. L Hermann, F. Stromeyer, and J.C.H. Roloff

tablerow.tablecell: All three found an unknown metal in a sample ofzinc oxidefrom Silesia, but the name that Stromeyer gave became the accepted one.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym48 CadmiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Jns Jakob BerzeliusJ. BerzeliusandJohann Gottlieb GahnG. Gahn

While working with lead they discovered a substance that they thought was tellurium, but realized after more investigation that it is different.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym34 SeleniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Humphry Davy thought in 1800 thatsilicawas an element, not a compound, and in 1808 suggested the present name. In 1811 Louis-Joseph Gay-Lussac and Louis-Jacques Thnard probably prepared impure silicon, but Berzelius is credited with the discovery for obtaining the pure element in 1824.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym14 SiliconElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Antoine Lavoisier predicted in 1787 thatalumineis the oxide of an undiscovered element, and in 1808 Humphry Davy tried to decompose it. Although he failed, he suggested the present name. Hans Christian rsted was the first to isolate metallic aluminium in 1825.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym13 AluminiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Antoine Jrme BalardJ. BalardandLeopold GmelinL. Gmelin
They both discovered the element in the autumn of 1825 and published the results the next year.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym35 BromineElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Berzelius obtained the oxide of a new earth inthorite.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym90 ThoriumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Mosander found a new element in samples of ceria and published his results in 1842, but later he showed that thislanthanacontained four more elements.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym57 LanthanumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Mosander managed to split the old yttria into yttria proper anderbia, and laterterbiatoo.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym68 ErbiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
In 1842 Mosander split yttria into two more earths, erbia and terbiacite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym65 TerbiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Gottfried Wilhelm Osannthought that he found three new metals in Russian platinum samples, and in 1844Karl Ernst ClausKarl Karlovich Klausconfirmed that there was a new element.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym44 RutheniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Robert BunsenR. BunsenandGustav KirchhoffR. Kirchhoff

Bunsen and Kirchhoff were the first to suggest finding new elements bySpectroscopyspectrum analysis. They discovered caesium by its two blueemission linesin a sample ofDrkheimmineral water.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym55 CaesiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12The pure metal was eventually isolated in 1882 by Setterberg.Caesium
R. Bunsen and G. R. Kirchhoff
R. Bunsen

Bunsen and Kirchhoff discovered it just a few months after caesium, by observing new spectral lines in the minerallepidolite. Bunsen never obtained a pure sample of the metal, which was later obtained by Hervesy.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym37 RubidiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Shortly after the discovery of rubidium, Crookes found a new green line in a selenium sample; later that year, Lamy found the element to be metallic.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym81 ThalliumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Ferdinand ReichF. ReichandHieronymous Theodor RichterT. Richter
T. Richter

Reich and Richter First identified it insphaleriteby its bright indigo-blue spectroscopic emission line. Richter isolated the metal several years later.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym49 IndiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Pierre JanssenP. JanssenandJoseph Norman LockyerN. Lockyer
Sir William RamsayW. Ramsay,Per Theodor CleveT. Cleve, andNils LangletN. Langlet

Janssen and Lockyer observed independently a yellow line in the solar spectrum that did not match any other element.Years later, Ramsay, Cleve, and Langlet observed independently the element trapped incleveiteabout the same time.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym02 HeliumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

tablerow.tablehead: Mendeleev arranges the 64 elements known at that time into the first modern periodic table and correctly predicts several others.

tablerow.tablecell: Boisbaudran observed on a pyreneablendesample some emission lines corresponding to the eka-aluminium that wasMendeleev's predicted elementspredictedby Mendeleev in 1871 and subsequently isolated the element by electrolysis.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym31 GalliumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

On October 22, 1878, Marignac reported splitting terbia into two new earths, terbia proper andytterbia.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym70 YtterbiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Delafontaine found it insamarskiteand next year, Per Teodor Cleve split Marignac's erbia into erbia proper and two new elements, thulium and holmium.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym67 HolmiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Cleve split Marignac's erbia into erbia proper and two new elements, thulium and holmium.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym69 ThuliumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Nilson split Marignac's ytterbia into pure ytterbia and a new element that matched 1871 Mendeleev's predicted eka-boron.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym21 ScandiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
P.E.L. de Boisbaudran
Boisbaudran noted a new earth in samarskite and named it samaria after the mineral.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym62 SamariumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
J. C. G. de Marignac

Marignac initially observed the new earth in terbia, and later Boisbaudran obtained a pure sample from samarskite.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym64 GadoliniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Von Welsbach discovered two new distinct elements in ceria: praseodymium and neodymium.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym59 PraseodymiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
A. von Welsbach
Von Welsbach discovered two new distinct elements in ceria: praseodymium and neodymium.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym60 NeodymiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
P.E.L. de Boisbaudran
De Boisbaudran found a new earth in erbia.
In February 1886 Winkler found inargyroditethe eka-silicon that Mendeleev had predicted in 1871.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym32 GermaniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
John Strutt, 3rd Baron RayleighLord RayleighandWilliam RamsayW. Ramsay

They discovered the gas by comparing the molecular weights of nitrogen prepared byLiquefaction of gasesliquefactionfrom air and nitrogen prepared by chemical means. It is the first noble gas to be isolated.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym18 ArgonElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
W. Ramsay andMorris W. TraversW. Travers
On May 30, 1898, Ramsay separated a noble gas from liquid argon by difference in boiling point.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym10 NeonElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
W. Ramsay and W. Travers
In June 1898 Ramsay separated a new noble gas from liquid argon by difference in boiling point.
W. Ramsay and W. Travers

On July 12, 1898 Ramsay separated a third noble gas within three weeks, from liquid argon by difference in boiling point.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym54 XenonElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Pierre CurieP.andMarie CurieM. Curie

In an experiment done on July 13, 1898, the Curies noted an increased radioactivity in the uranium obtained frompitchblende, which they ascribed to an unknown element.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym84 PoloniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
P. and M. Curie
M. Curie

The Curies reported on December 26, 1898, a new element different from polonium, which Marie later isolated fromuraninite.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym88 RadiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
W. Ramsay andRobert Whytlaw-GrayR. Whytlaw-Gray

Dorn discovered a radioactive gas resulting from the radioactive decay of radium, isolated later by Ramsay and Gray.cite journalDiscovery of Radon[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]1794566912May 1957Partington, J. R.10.1038/179912a01957Natur.179..912Pcite journalLa densité de l'emanation du radiumRamsay, W.; Gray, R. W.Comptes rendus hebdomadaires des séances de l'Académie des sciences151126–1281910http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k31042/f126.table
Debierne obtained from pitchblende a substance that had properties similar to those of thorium.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym89 ActiniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Demaray found spectral lines of a new element in Lecoq's samarium, and separated this element several years later.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym63 EuropiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Georges UrbainG. UrbainandCarl Auer von WelsbachC.A. von Welsbach

tablecell.italics: G. Urbain and C.A. von Welsbach

tablerow.tablecell: Urbain and von Welsbach proved independently that the oldytterbiumalso contained a new element.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym71 LutetiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12

Ogawa found it inthorianitebut assigned it as element 43 instead of 75 and named itnipponium.http://www.maik.ru/abstract/radchem/0/radchem0535_abstract.pdfIn 1922Walter Noddack,Ida NoddackIda Eva TackeandOtto Berg (scientist)Otto Bergannounced its separation fromgadoliniteand gave it the present name.
Georges UrbainG. UrbainandVladimir VernadskyV. Vernadsky
Dirk CosterD. CosterandGeorg von HevesyG. von Hevesy

Urbain claimed to have found the element in rare-earth residues, while Vernadsky independently found it inorthite. Neither claim was confirmed due toWorld War I. After the war, Coster and Hevesy found it by X-ray spectroscopic analysis in Norwegian zircon.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym72 HafniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12Hafnium was the last stable element to be discovered.cite journalNoddack, W.; Tacke, I.; Berg, ODie EkamanganeNaturwissenschaften19251356710.1007/BF015587461925NW.....13..567.26
Oswald Helmuth GhringO.H.GhringandKasimir FajansK. Fajans

The two obtained the first isotope of this element that had been predicted by Mendeleev in 1871 as a member of the natural decay of238U.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym91 ProtactiniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12Originally isolated in 1900 by William Crookes.cite bookEmsleyJohnNature's Building Blocks(Hardcover, First Edition)[[Oxford University Press]]20013470-19-850340-7
Carlo PerrierC. PerrierandEmilio SegrE. Segr

The two discovered a new element in a molybdenum sample that was used in acyclotron, the firstsynthetic elementto be discovered. It had been predicted by Mendeleev in 1871 as eka-manganese.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym43 TechnetiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12History of the Origin of the Chemical Elements and Their Discoverers, Individual Element Names and History, "Technetium"

Perey discovered it as a decay product of227Ac.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym87 FranciumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12Francium is the last element to be discovered in nature, rather than synthesized in the lab, although some of the "synthetic" elements that were discovered later (plutonium, neptunium, astatine) were eventually found in trace amounts in nature as well.Adloff, Jean-Pierre; Kaufman, George B. (2005-09-25).Francium (Atomic Number 87), the Last Discovered Natural Element.The Chemical Educator10(5). [2007-03-26]
Dale R. CorsonR. Corson,Kenneth Ross MacKenzieR. MacKenzieandEmilio SegrE. Segr

Obtained by bombarding bismuth with alpha particles.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym85 AstatineElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12Later determined to occur naturally in minuscule quantities (<25 grams in earth's crust).cite bookCloseFrank E.Particle Physics: A Very Short IntroductionOxford University Press20042978-0-19-280434-1http://books.google.com/books?id
Edwin McMillanE.M. McMillanandPhilip H. AbelsonH. Abelson
Obtained by irradiating uranium with neutrons, it is the firsttransuranium elementdiscovered.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym93 NeptuniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Glenn T. Seaborg,Arthur WahlArthur C. Wahl,Joseph W. KennedyW. Kennedyand E.M. McMillan
Prepared by bombardment of uranium with deuterons.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym94 PlutoniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
G. T. Seaborg,Ralph A. JamesA. James,Leon O. MorganO. MorganandAlbert GhiorsoA. Ghiorso
Prepared by irradiating plutonium with neutrons during theManhattan Project.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym95 AmericiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
G. T. Seaborg, R. A. James and A. Ghiorso
Prepared by bombarding plutonium with alpha particles during the Manhattan Projectcite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym96 CuriumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Chien Shiung WuS. Wu,Emilio G. SegrE.G. SegrandHans Albrecht BetheA. Bethe
Charles D. Coryell,Jacob A. Marinsky,Lawrence E. Glendenin, andHarold G. Richter

It was probably first prepared in 1942 by bombarding neodymium and praseodymium with neutrons, but separation of the element could not be carried out. Isolation was performed under the Manhattan Project in 1945.
Stanley G. ThompsonG. Thompson, A. Ghiorso and G. T. Seaborg(University of California, Berkeley)
Created by bombardment of americium with alpha particles.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym97 BerkeliumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
S. G. Thompson,Kenneth Street, Jr.K. Street,Jr., A. Ghiorso and G. T. Seaborg(University of California, Berkeley)
Bombardment of curium with alpha particles.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym98 CaliforniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
A. Ghiorso et al.(Argonne Laboratory,Los Alamos Laboratoryand University of California, Berkeley)

Formed in the first thermonuclear explosion in November 1952, by irradiation of uranium with neutrons; kept secret for several years.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym99 EinsteiniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
A. Ghiorso et al.(Argonne Laboratory, Los Alamos Laboratory and University of California, Berkeley)

Formed in the first thermonuclear explosion in November 1952, by irradiation of uranium with neutrons; kept secret for several years.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym100 FermiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
A. Ghiorso,Bernard G. HarveyG. Harvey,Gregory R. ChoppinR. Choppin, S. G. Thompson and G. T. Seaborg
Prepared by bombardment of einsteinium with helium.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym101 MendeleviumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
A. Ghiorso,Torbjrn SikkelandT. Sikkeland,J.R. WaltonR. Waltonand G. T. Seaborg
First prepared by bombardment of curium with carbon atoms.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym102 NobeliumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
A. Ghiorso, T. Sikkeland,Almon E. LarshE. LarshandRobert M. LatimerM. Latimer
First prepared by bombardment of californium with boron atoms.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym103 LawrenciumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
A. Ghiorso,Matti NurmiaM. Nurmia,James Andrew HarrisJ. Harris,Kari EskolaK. EskolaandPirkko EskolaP. Eskola
Prepared by bombardment of californium with carbon atoms.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym104 RutherfordiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
A. Ghiorso, M. Nurmia, K. Eskola, J. Harris and P. Eskola
Prepared by bombardment of californium with nitrogen atoms.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym105 DubniumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
A. Ghiorso,J. Michael NitschkeJ. Nitschke,Jose Alonso (atomic physicist)J. Alonso,Carol AlonsoC. Alonso, M. Nurmia, G. T. Seaborg,Ken HuletK. HuletandRonald W. LougheedW. Lougheed
Prepared by collisions of californium-249 with oxygen atoms.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym106 SeaborgiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
Gottfried MnzenbergG.Mnzenberget al.(GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion ResearchGSI in Darmstadt)
Obtained by bombarding bismuth with chromium.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym107 BohriumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
G. Mnzenberg,Peter ArmbrusterP. Armbrusteret al.(GSI in Darmstadt)
Prepared by bombardment of bismuth with iron atoms.cite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym109 MeitneriumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
G. Mnzenberg, P. Armbruster et al.(GSI in Darmstadt)
Prepared by bombardment of lead with iron atomscite webhttp://elements.vanderkrogt.net/element.php?sym108 HassiumElements.vanderkrogt.net2008-09-12
